inlineContent.text: AudioKit 5.3 is a Swift-only package, so it should be usable on iPad’s Swift Playgrounds app.  To allow for this, AudioKitEX has been moved to its own package, so you will likely have to update your package dependencies to also include AudioKitEX.

This version update involves separating AudioKit into separate Sub-AudioKits which are included as separate Swift Packages. This way, developers do not have to compile code that their apps don’t require. Most users will probably have to include the SoundpipeAudioKit package since that is the one that contained many of the oscillators, effects, and filters. In addition to including the packages, developers may also have to update their files to import the correct frameworks.
Also, please note that some types that did not move into a new
lives in the base AudioKit package, but code that references it will need to import the
module that is included in that package.
Here is a list of types that moved into a new package, and where they live now.
The major change in AudioKit 5.1 is that the
class was changed to be a
protocol.  The parameters and parameter definition system was cleaned up as well. While these are big changes that warrant the version change, they shouldn’t affect most users.

In order to ensure high quality for AudioKit 5, some parts of AudioKit 4 have been removed, so the first step in migrating to AudioKit 5 is to determine whether what you used in AudioKit 4 is still available.
So, first we’ll start out with a list of things that are just not in AudioKit 5 in any form:
but doesn’t include the AudioKit’s 4’s other players
. Some of these classes had utility and could/should be brought back to AudioKit 5.
have all been removed. They were coded in a way that we have since outgrown. The only polyphonic node left is
but we intend on bringing back polyphonic instruments in a well-coded way as soon as possible.
Inter-App Audio support has been removed. Apple has deprecated it and Audiobus now supports Apple’s AUv3 format, which should work even better than Inter-App Audio.
was removed. A project to demonstrate this functionality has been started
has been removed. Its easy enough to create a metronome with
and one track. This will be demonstrated in the Cookbook examples project.
The following items have been very significantly changed, even if their names are similar:
has been removed. We have found Apple’s
sufficient for this purpose now. Format conversion is now handled by AudioKit 5’s
have all been removed. In its place we have
The following taps have been removed:
. Instead, we have traditional AVAudioEngine style taps:
Next we have things that are different but rather trivial to reimplement (and very worthwhile to do so).

The best way to use AudioKit 5 is to use Swift Package Manager. If you’re hooked on Cocoapods, we still plan to provide Cocoapod versions, but we strongly encourage you to move to SPM. We have, and we do not regret it.
that has AudioKit as a dependency.
The AudioKit singleton no longer exists so instead of writing
you’ll need to create an instance of an AudioKit Engine:
instead. If you already have defined an
class in your project, you can access AudioKit’s oscillator with
AudioKit 5 effects no longer take optional nodes on initialization.
but now you will have to write

. One of the main reasons for this is that our audio engine is keeping track of the connections and now tightly enforces that you’re not making any mistakes with dangling nodes not properly connected.
A side effect of this change is that the syntactical sugar of setting up your chain after initialization with the syntax
is gone. To change your signal chain, even while the engine is running, use a
Ramp duration is no longer a property of AudioKit or even on AudioKit nodes. Instead, ramping parameters is much more flexible.  What used to be:
Notice how ramping duration is independent for each parameter. And notice the parameter is a
in this case, so it is prefixed by the dollar sign. Setting parameters like in the first code still works, but the changes are immediate, not ramped.
In addition to all parameters on AudioKit nodes (except for the ones based off of Apple DSP) being rampable, they are also automatable.  By generating
curves, you can approximate all kinds of ramp curves or other time varying changes to the parameters.
Microphone access has changed. There is no more
and instead you create a microphone as an
and instantiate on an engine you create:
All of the projects in the Examples for have been moved out of this repository. See the
documentary for links to the new repositories.
This syntactical sugar for connecting nodes has been removed.
This class was never tested and seemed to not work well.
This was a part of the AKPlayer. Use AudioPlayer instead.
Everything has been updated to use Apple’s AVAudioFile. Use FormatConverter to change the format of an AVAudioFile.

abstract.text: Swift audio synthesis, processing, & analysis platform for iOS, macOS and tvOS
